transcripts.text: When I did my last IQ and aptitude test, I was taken into a separate room and I was interrogated to see if I'd cheated.

They then mutated again so they could infect human cells. You cannot catch a virus.  And why can't you catch a virus?  Because it's impossible.

Well, given that some sources are suggesting that the first case was actually reported in China as early as the 17th of November, and given that at the time of the making of this video, we now have, I don't know, a shitload of cases, it would appear that this virus can actually spread.  But how?  Well, we all know that limiting human contact is very important.  In the early part of the outbreak, Russia closed its borders with China before it even had a single reported case.  As a result of that, it now just sits at 0.9 deaths per million of its population, truly showing that early action to stop people mixing can be very effective.  So why is it then that COVID-19 appears to spread so quickly when compared with other outbreaks?  Well, some early estimates place COVID-19's R0 value anywhere near as high as 3.  Now an R0 value basically tells us how many people on average will be infected by somebody else who has the virus.  This graph here shows us a very, very stark picture of just how much more aggressively a virus with an R0 value of around 3 will rip through a population, compared to even a virus with an R0 value of 2.6.  To put that into perspective, the flu has an R0 value between 1.4 and 1.6, giving us a line that's even flatter than the purple line on this graph.  But why does it spread so quickly?  Well, we all know that COVID-19 can be spread through sneezing.  But unlike the flu, the COVID-19 virus can survive in those tiny water droplets for far longer.  It was believed that the flu virus, for example, could remain able to infect outside of the body for anything up to 48 hours.  But more recent research suggests that actually under normal conditions, this number is far, far lower.  In fact, just a few hours.  Whereas current evidence is suggesting that COVID-19 could remain able to infect in water droplets on hard surfaces for days.  In addition to that, COVID-19 can also be sustained in faecal matter, making the faecal-oral transmission route a possibility.  Some suggest that even two people in separate apartments in the same building that share poor plumbing can be part of the same transmission chain. So how exactly does COVID-19 harm the body?  This is the ursac or alveoli in the lung.  This is where necessary gas exchange takes place.  In other words we absorb oxygen into our blood and we lose carbon dioxide from our blood.  Now inside the alveoli we have these type 1 alveolar cells.  Their job is to facilitate this gas exchange and they are very very thin to allow it to happen.  But just as importantly we also have type 2 alveolar cells and their job is to reduce the surface tension within the alveoli which stops the alveoli from collapsing.  Now it's these type 2 cells that do get invaded by COVID-19 and that means if the body doesn't respond eventually the alveoli will collapse preventing that all-important gas exchange.  But the body does respond to this infection and the white blood cells release chemicals called interleukins.  Now there's a lot of interleukins but we're concerned about number one and number six.  But these interleukins also cause an inflammatory response which draws fluid out of the capillaries that are surrounding the alveoli.  This puts a physical pressure on the ursac and again can cause it to collapse.  Or this extra fluid can also enter the alveoli blocking off gas exchange as if we were drowning.  Now this of course makes it incredibly difficult to breathe, causing the patient to expend an incredible amount of energy gasping for breath, and this is why ventilators are so important.  Now while all that's going on, the same interleukins that cause that inflammatory response trigger the hypothalamus to raise the temperature of the body, resulting in a fever.  Now the damage to the alveoli obviously decreases the amount of oxygen we can take into our blood.  And that causes the heart to work faster, to pump faster, to desperately try and get whatever oxygen is in the blood around the body.  And you might think that that will have the effect of increasing blood pressure.  But actually, if the inflammatory response we talked about before spreads to other parts of the body, then we can lose an enormous amount of fluid from the blood, which actually causes a massive drop in blood pressure.
